title: Romance & Passion
description: Explore what keeps the spark alive in your relationship.

questions.text: What romance means to me is...
choices: Thoughtful gestures that show you're thinking of me
Quality time focused entirely on us
Physical affection and closeness
Words that express love and desire

therapeutic.rationale: Romance definitions vary like love languages. Gesture-lovers want tangible care; time-lovers want presence; touch-lovers want physical closeness; word-lovers want verbal expression. Knowing your partner's definition helps you romance them well.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different definitions mean different effort. The gesture-lover may not feel romanced by words alone; the word-lover may not notice gestures without verbal context. Learn each other's definition.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared romance definition makes romantic efforts land. You naturally give what your partner wants.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What feels romantic to you? Think of a time you felt truly romancedâ€”what made it special?

questions.text: Keeping passion alive in a relationship requires...
choices: Intentional effort and prioritization
Novelty and trying new things together
Maintaining emotional connection first
Making time despite busy lives

therapeutic.rationale: Passion maintenance beliefs shape behavior. Effort-believers prioritize; novelty-seekers introduce variety; connection-focusers maintain emotional depth; time-makers protect together-time. All approaches can work.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs may mean different efforts. The novelty-seeker may feel the connection-focuser is boring; the connection-focuser may feel the novelty-seeker is shallow. Both contribute to passion.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared belief aligns your passion maintenance efforts. You'll invest in the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you think keeps passion alive? Are you doing those things?

questions.text: The romantic gesture that would mean most to me is...
choices: A surprise planned with thought and care
Simple daily expressions of love
Creating special memories together
Physical expressions of desire and attraction

therapeutic.rationale: Gesture preferences reveal what makes you feel loved. Surprise-lovers want planned effort; daily-expression lovers want consistency; memory-makers want shared experiences; physical-lovers want desire shown. These preferences guide romantic giving.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different preferences mean adjusting your giving. The surprise-lover may not feel romanced by daily expressions alone. Learn what your partner most values.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared preference makes romantic giving intuitive. You naturally want the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What romantic gesture would make you feel incredibly loved? Have you told your partner?

questions.text: I feel most desired by my partner when they...
choices: Tell me directly that they want me
Initiate physical closeness
Look at me in a certain way
Make me a priority over other things

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling desired matters deeply, but what triggers that feeling varies. Tell-me types need verbal; initiators-respond types feel wanted when pursued; look-readers notice expressions; priority-needers feel desired through attention. Know your partner's trigger.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different triggers mean different expressions. The verbal-needer may not feel desired by looks alone; the priority-needer may not feel desired without tangible time.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trigger makes expressing desire effectively easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When do you feel most desired by your partner? What makes you feel wanted?

questions.text: The balance of comfort and excitement I want in our intimate life is...
choices: Mostly comfortable with sparks of excitement
Regular excitement with comfortable foundation
Depends on the season of life
Deep comfort is more important than excitement

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort-excitement balance is personal. Comfort-preferers want security with occasional spark; excitement-seekers want more stimulation; flexible types adapt; depth-seekers prioritize emotional safety. Partners often differ here.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different balance preferences need negotiation. The excitement-seeker may feel the comfort-preferer is boring; the comfort-preferer may feel the excitement-seeker is exhausting. Find your sustainable balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared balance preference aligns your expectations. You're aiming for the same kind of intimate life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What balance of comfort and excitement feels right to you? Is that what you have now?
